citeinfo.origin: D. Caldwell Hahn and Robert C. Fleischer
U.S. Geological Survey, Biological Resources Division, Patuxent Wildlife Research Center
citeinfo.title: DNA Fingerprint Similarity between Female and Juvenile Brown-Headed Cowbirds Trapped Together

pubinfo.publish: U.S. Geological Survey, Biological Resources Division, Patuxent Wildlife Research Center

citeinfo.origin: U.S. Geological Survey, Biological Resources Division, Patuxent Wildlife Research Center
citeinfo.title: Brood Parasitism on Neotropical Migrants

pubinfo.publish: U.S. Geological Survey, Biological Resources Division, Patuxent Wildlife Research Center

descript.abstract: This DNA fingerprinting study investigates whether females of the brood parasite brown-headed cowbird, Molothrus ater, associate with their own juvenile ffspring at feeding sites more often than would be expected by chance. Cowbirds lay their eggs in the nests of a variety of host species and, as far as is known, leave them to the care of foster parents. Using baited walk-in funnel traps, 36 adult female-juvenile pairs (or trios) of cowbirds were trapped. Blood samples were collected from these individuals to conduct DNA fingerprinting analyses, calculate similarity indices, and to compare S-values for the 11 comparisons of juveniles and the females with which they were caught with S-values of random pairings of juveniles and the females in adjacent gel lanes with which they were not caught. Overall band-sharing was significantly higher for the individuals trapped together than for the random pairings. These associations between juvenile cowbirds and their mothers could occur as a result of female cowbirds monitoring the development of their young in the nests where they have laid. Alternatively, nestling cowbirds in the nest could become familiar visually and vocally with a female parent that is frequently present in their territory and could follow her when she departs for feeding grounds. In either case these data suggest that adult cowbirds associate with juveniles, in some cases their own offspring, and that offspring may learn to function as cowbirds in part from this association.
descript.purpose: To gather information about cowbird ( Moluthrus ater) brood parasitism, parasitism rates, fingerprint similarity
descript.supplinf:
Information for this metadata was adapted from the U.S. Geological Survey, Biological Resources Division, Patuxent Wildlife Research Center Showcase site at http://www.pwrc.usgs.gov/resshow/hahn1rs/hahn1rs.h tm. Internal Filename - usgsbrdpwrc00000019. A digital copy of this metadata file is available in text, html, and sgml format on the National Biological Information Infrastructure (NBII) Metadata Clearinghouse.
The previous online linkage was determined to be broken in October 2010 and moved here. The previous online linkage was:
http://www.pwrc.usgs.gov/resshow/hahn1rs/hahn1rs.h tm

method.methdesc: Using baited walk-in funnel traps, 36 adult female-juvenile pairs (or trios) of cowbirds were trapped. Blood samples were collected from these individuals to conduct DNA fingerprinting analyses.

procstep.procdesc: Similarity indices were calculated, and S-values for the 11 comparisons of juveniles and the females with which they were caught were compared with S-values of random pairings of juveniles and the females in adjacent gel lanes with which they were not caught. Overall band-sharing was significantly higher for the individuals trapped together than for the random pairings. These associations between juvenile cowbirds and their mothers could occur as a result of female cowbirds monitoring the development of their young in the nests where they have laid. Alternatively, nestling cowbirds in the nest could become familiar visually and vocally with a female parent that is frequently present in their territory and could follow her when she departs for feeding grounds. In either case these data suggest that adult cowbirds associate with juveniles, in some cases their own offspring, and that offspring may learn to function as cowbirds in part from this association.

distinfo.distliab: Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the U.S. Geological Survey, no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the accuracy or utility of the data on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. This disclaimer applies both to individual use of the data and aggregate use with other data. It is strongly recommended that these data are directly acquired from a U.S. Geological Survey server, and not indirectly through other sources which may have changed the data in some way. It is also strongly recommended that careful attention be paid to the contents of the metadata file associated with these data.
